name: Peter Popp
focus_summary: Pioneer of fulldome storytelling who has directed some of the medium’s most widely distributed educational and family shows.

key_works.title: The Life of Trees
key_works.notes: Award-winning fulldome show explaining the role of trees in Earth’s ecosystem through animated characters and omni-stereoscopic 3D imagery.

key_works.title: Little Major Tom: Into the Unknown
key_works.notes: Sci-fi adventure based on the children’s book series, produced with musician Peter Schilling for exclusive fulldome distribution.

key_works.title: KIRA – Script and Concept Development
key_works.notes: Lead writer and concept developer for the centennial fulldome film KIRA, commissioned by the International Planetarium Society.

short_bio: Dr. Peter Popp is a German filmmaker, founder of Softmachine and Reef Distribution, and one of the most influential directors in fulldome cinema. His work combines narrative animation with scientific content, and his shows have been licensed to hundreds of planetariums around the world.

references.title: The Life of Trees – Fulldome Show
Little Major Tom: Into the Unknown

name: Francesca Panetta
focus_summary: British immersive director and journalist pioneering VR and AI-driven narrative experiences that translate complex social and political issues into embodied stories.

key_works.title: 6x9: A Virtual Experience of Solitary Confinement
key_works.venue_or_context: The Guardian VR; Sundance and Tribeca showcases
key_works.notes: Seminal VR journalism piece placing viewers in a solitary confinement cell to expose the psychological impact of isolation.

key_works.title: In Event of Moon Disaster
key_works.venue_or_context: MIT Center for Advanced Virtuality; multiple festivals and museums
key_works.notes: Emmy-winning interactive documentary using deepfake video to imagine a failed Apollo 11 mission and teach critical media literacy.

key_works.title: First Impressions
key_works.notes: Immersive project exploring how babies perceive the world, combining developmental research with experiential storytelling.

short_bio: Francesca Panetta is an Emmy award-winning immersive artist, director and journalist whose work bridges investigative reporting and cutting-edge media technologies. At The Guardian she led the in-house VR and immersive team, producing projects like 6x9 that defined early standards for VR journalism. As creative director at MIT’s Center for Advanced Virtuality and later Director of the AKO Storytelling Institute at UAL, she has continued to explore VR, AR and AI as tools for social impact storytelling and critical media literacy.

references.title: Home – Francesca Panetta
references.notes: Official site outlining Panetta’s immersive projects, roles at MIT and UAL, and focus on storytelling for social change.

references.title: Francesca Panetta – Biography
references.notes: Institutional profile describing her role as Director of the AKO Storytelling Institute and her background in immersive journalism.

references.title: Exploring VR Journalism Through 6x9: An Immersive Experience of Solitary Confinement
references.notes: Article discussing the 6x9 VR project and its role in advancing immersive journalism.

name: Es Devlin
focus_summary: Creates large-scale performative sculptures and stage environments for concerts, ceremonies, and exhibitions, often using light, language, and sound to transform spaces into immersive environments.

key_works.title: London 2012 Olympics Closing Ceremony (Design)
key_works.notes: Co-designed the closing ceremony, using large-scale staging and projection to create an immersive ‘symphony of British music’ in the stadium.

key_works.title: Forest of Us
key_works.notes: Immersive installation of mirrored labyrinths and projections exploring the analogy between trees and human bronchial systems.

key_works.title: Congregation
key_works.notes: Immersive choral installation featuring projection-mapped portraits and sound, developed with UK for UNHCR.

short_bio: Es Devlin is a British artist and stage designer recognised for transforming theatres, stadiums, and public spaces into immersive environments. Her work for major concert tours, Olympic ceremonies, and installations such as Forest of Us positions her as a central figure at the intersection of performance, architecture, and large-scale immersive art.

name: Char Davies
focus_summary: Pioneering artist of immersive virtual environments using head-mounted displays and breath/balance interfaces to explore embodiment and perception.

key_works.title: Osmose
key_works.venue_or_context: First shown at ISEA 1995, Montreal; later at museums and media art venues worldwide
key_works.notes: Immersive VR environment navigated via breath and balance, considered a landmark in early artistic virtual reality.

key_works.title: Éphémère
key_works.venue_or_context: International media art exhibitions and research labs
key_works.notes: VR artwork extending Osmose’s approach to time-based cycles of landscape, body, and subterranean spaces.

short_bio: Char Davies is a Canadian artist widely recognised for the immersive VR works Osmose and Éphémère, which use biofeedback interfaces and translucent 3D environments to explore embodiment and perception in virtual space. Her projects are often cited as foundational works in artistic virtual reality and immersive media.

name: Gabo Arora
focus_summary: Directs VR documentaries for humanitarian organisations, using immersive media to increase empathy and engagement around global crises.

key_works.title: Clouds Over Sidra
key_works.venue_or_context: World Economic Forum, Davos; UN events; VR festivals and campaigns
key_works.notes: 360° documentary set in the Za’atari Syrian refugee camp, co-created with Chris Milk for the United Nations, often cited as a key early ‘VR for good’ project.

key_works.title: Waves of Grace
key_works.venue_or_context: UN Millennium Campaign, VR festivals, Within platform
key_works.notes: VR film about an Ebola survivor in Liberia, co-directed with Chris Milk, used by the UN to raise awareness and support for post-epidemic recovery.

key_works.title: Ground Beneath Her
key_works.notes: VR documentary following a teenager after the Nepal earthquake, continuing Arora’s focus on immersive humanitarian storytelling.

short_bio: Gabo Arora is an American filmmaker, immersive artist, and former UN Creative Director known for pioneering humanitarian VR documentaries such as Clouds Over Sidra and Waves of Grace. His work uses virtual reality to immerse viewers in refugee camps, disaster zones, and post-crisis communities, influencing how NGOs and institutions approach immersive storytelling.

name: Chris Milk
focus_summary: Bridges interactive art, music video, and VR to create emotionally driven immersive experiences and co-founds key VR production and distribution studios.

key_works.title: Clouds Over Sidra
key_works.venue_or_context: UN, World Economic Forum, festivals, Within platform
key_works.notes: Co-creator and producer of the UN’s first VR film, which follows a Syrian girl in Za’atari refugee camp and helped catalyse the ‘VR for good’ movement.

key_works.title: Waves of Grace
key_works.venue_or_context: UN Millennium Campaign, Vice, Within platform
key_works.notes: Co-director of a VR documentary about an Ebola survivor in Liberia, produced by Vrse/Within with the United Nations and Vice.

short_bio: Chris Milk is an American filmmaker and immersive artist, co-founder and former CEO of VR company Within (formerly Vrse) and co-founder of the VR production studio Here Be Dragons. After an early career in music videos and commercials, he became a central figure in VR storytelling through projects like Clouds Over Sidra and Waves of Grace.

name: Jessica Brillhart
focus_summary: Develops VR films and theories of immersive editing, focusing on how viewers navigate story and music in 360° environments.

key_works.title: Beethoven’s Fifth
key_works.venue_or_context: Philharmonia Orchestra / Google Daydream, VR release
key_works.notes: VR film placing the viewer inside the Philharmonia Orchestra during Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony, commissioned by Daydream and directed by Brillhart.

key_works.title: Various VR works for Google, NASA and partners
key_works.venue_or_context: Google VR projects, cultural institutions and festivals
key_works.notes: Series of VR experiences exploring music, space, and embodied viewpoint, contributing to early best practices in VR filmmaking.

short_bio: Jessica Brillhart is an American immersive director and theorist known for pioneering VR editing techniques and directing high-profile VR experiences. As Google’s former Principal Filmmaker for VR, she helped define approaches to immersive narrative and later continued her work through her studio on projects with orchestras, tech companies, and research organisations.

name: Aaron Koblin
focus_summary: Combines data visualisation, interactive art, and VR product design as co-founder of Within and former head of Google’s Data Arts Team.

key_works.title: Within (formerly Vrse) – Co-founder & President
key_works.venue_or_context: VR/AR platform and productions including Clouds Over Sidra, Supernatural
key_works.notes: Co-founded the VR company that produced and distributed many early landmark VR experiences and later the fitness platform Supernatural.

key_works.title: Google Data Arts Team projects
key_works.venue_or_context: Google Chrome Experiments, web-based installations and exhibitions
key_works.notes: Directed interactive and data-art projects that informed later immersive and XR work through experimental interfaces and real-time graphics.

short_bio: Aaron Koblin is a data artist and creative director, co-founder and former President of VR/AR studio Within and founder of Google’s Data Arts Team. His work sits between interactive data visualisation, art, and product design, and he has played a significant role in shaping how immersive platforms integrate design, storytelling, and technology.

name: Ryoji Ikeda
focus_summary: Creates large-scale, often architecturally scaled audiovisual environments where light, code, and sound form overwhelming immersive fields.

key_works.title: test pattern
key_works.venue_or_context: Series of installations at venues worldwide including Times Square and 180 The Strand
key_works.notes: Audiovisual installation converting data and sound into flickering black-and-white patterns on screens and large projections, enveloping visitors in rhythmic light and noise.

key_works.title: the transfinite
key_works.notes: Monumental projection and sound installation filling the Armory’s hall with a luminous data-field, inviting visitors to walk through an overwhelming digital landscape.

short_bio: Ryoji Ikeda is a Japanese composer and artist known for mathematically precise, high-contrast sound and light environments. Works such as test pattern and the transfinite use projection, LED, and multichannel audio to turn architectural spaces into immersive data-scapes.

name: Bob Rogers
focus_summary: Designs narrative-driven attractions and brand experiences for world expos, museums, and theme parks as founder of BRC Imagination Arts.

key_works.title: Impressions de France (Circle-Vision 360)
key_works.notes: Panoramic multi-screen film for Disney’s France pavilion, an early example of immersive 360° cinema in themed entertainment.

key_works.title: Ghosts of the Library
key_works.venue_or_context: Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, Springfield, Illinois
key_works.notes: Holavision theatre show combining live performance with ‘floating’ projected imagery to immerse visitors in Lincoln’s legacy.

key_works.title: World Expo pavilions and brand homes
key_works.venue_or_context: Multiple world expos and corporate visitor centres
key_works.notes: Creative direction for numerous award-winning pavilions and brand experiences that mix film, effects, and architecture into integrated immersive storytelling.

short_bio: Bob Rogers is an American designer, producer, and director, and the founder of BRC Imagination Arts. For over four decades he has created immersive attractions, world expo pavilions, and branded experiences for clients ranging from Disney and NASA to global consumer brands, helping define the language of narrative-driven themed environments.

name: Tsai Ming-liang
focus_summary: Acclaimed auteur filmmaker who extends his slow cinema aesthetics into VR, using 360° space as an intimate, contemplative environment.

key_works.title: The Deserted (VR)
key_works.venue_or_context: Venice Film Festival VR Theatre, Lazzaretto Vecchio; HTC Vive Originals
key_works.notes: 55-minute VR film produced with HTC’s Virtual Reality Content Center, premiered in Venice’s first dedicated VR competition and screened in a custom VR theatre on Lazzaretto Island.

short_bio: Tsai Ming-liang is a Taiwan-based filmmaker celebrated for his slow, contemplative cinema. With The Deserted, he brought his style into virtual reality, creating one of the first feature-length Chinese-language VR films and contributing to the emergence of VR sections at major festivals such as Venice.

references.title: Tsai Ming-liang on The Deserted and VR

name: Stuart "Sutu" Campbell
focus_summary: Combines comics, illustration, and immersive media to create VR and AR stories, often in collaboration with communities and major entertainment franchises.

key_works.title: VR art for Doctor Strange and Ready Player One
key_works.venue_or_context: Commercial VR art commissions for Marvel, Google, and Warner Bros.
key_works.notes: Commissioned to create VR artwork expanding the worlds of major film franchises, demonstrating how illustration and concept art translate into immersive media.

key_works.title: Inside Manus, Mind at War, The Battle of Hamel
key_works.venue_or_context: VR documentaries for SBS, Ryot Films and the Australian War Memorial
key_works.notes: Series of VR documentaries addressing detention, war, and history, bringing Sutu’s visual language into non-fiction immersive storytelling.

key_works.title: Neomad and Nawlz (interactive comics)
key_works.notes: Digital comics projects that anticipated later immersive work through multi-layered, interactive storyworlds.

short_bio: Stuart "Sutu" Campbell is an Australian artist and director who works across interactive comics, VR, and AR. He has been commissioned by Marvel, Google, and Disney for VR art tied to major film properties and co-founded the AR platform EyeJack, while also producing socially engaged projects with remote communities.

references.title: SUTU (Stuart Campbell) – AWE Hall of Fame

name: Tino Schaedler
focus_summary: Designs hybrid physical-digital environments for brands, films, and events, exploring how virtual production and VR can extend architectural space.

key_works.title: Odyssey
key_works.notes: VR experience created with Optimist Design and United Realities, transporting viewers from a scanned real space into an imagined world, presented as the festival’s first VR installation at Somerset House.

key_works.title: Immersive brand and pop-up experiences
key_works.venue_or_context: Projects for clients including Google, Nike, and Disney
key_works.notes: Campaigns and spaces that weave physical architecture with digital media, often using VR and AR to extend brand storytelling.

short_bio: Tino Schaedler is a production designer, art director, and architect who works at the intersection of film, brand experiences, and immersive media. As chief design officer at Optimist and a specialist in virtual production and VR, he develops environments where spatial design, narrative, and interactive technology merge.

references.title: Tino Schaedler – Journey from the physical to the virtual
Tino Schaedler – World Building Institute profile

name: James Turrell
focus_summary: Light and Space artist who turns architecture itself into an immersive instrument for perceiving light and sky.

key_works.title: Roden Crater
key_works.notes: Ongoing transformation of a volcanic crater into a naked-eye observatory composed of carefully shaped light and skyview chambers.

key_works.title: Skyspaces (series)
key_works.venue_or_context: Sites worldwide, including MoMA PS1 and ARoS Aarhus
key_works.notes: Architectural rooms with apertures to the sky that use controlled light to alter viewers’ perception of colour and space.

short_bio: James Turrell is an American artist associated with the Light and Space movement whose practice focuses on the experience of light in constructed environments. Through works such as his Skyspaces and the Roden Crater project, he has defined a model for immersive art that uses architecture and light as primary materials.

name: Olafur Eliasson
focus_summary: Creates large-scale environments of light, weather, and optical effects that turn museums and public spaces into immersive landscapes.

key_works.title: The Weather Project
key_works.notes: Iconic installation that filled the Turbine Hall with an artificial sun, mist, and a mirrored ceiling, inviting visitors to lie down and inhabit the created climate.

key_works.title: Your Rainbow Panorama
key_works.notes: Circular rooftop walkway in coloured glass, turning the cityscape into a 360° immersive colour experience.

short_bio: Olafur Eliasson is a Danish–Icelandic artist whose studio in Berlin creates installations that use light, water, mirrors, and climate effects to stage immersive situations. Works such as The Weather Project and Your Rainbow Panorama exemplify his interest in how viewers co-create space and atmosphere.

name: Pipilotti Rist
focus_summary: Pioneer of spatial video art who turns galleries into colourful, walk-in video environments.

key_works.title: Pour Your Body Out (7354 Cubic Meters)
key_works.notes: Commissioned site-specific installation that filled MoMA’s Marron Atrium with monumental moving images and seating islands, inviting visitors to recline and inhabit the projection space.

short_bio: Pipilotti Rist is a Swiss artist known for immersive multi-channel video installations that envelop viewers in saturated colour and sound. Her work often explores the body, femininity, and nature through dreamlike projected environments.

references.title: Pipilotti Rist: Pour Your Body Out (7354 Cubic Meters)

name: Doug Aitken
focus_summary: Creates multi-screen video installations and 360° projections that wrap buildings and interiors in moving images and sound.

key_works.title: SONG 1
key_works.venue_or_context: Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Washington, D.C.
key_works.notes: Seven-channel video projection using 11 projectors to cover the museum’s circular exterior with a 360° film set to ‘I Only Have Eyes for You’.

key_works.title: electric earth
key_works.notes: Multi-projection installation that won the Venice Biennale’s International Prize and helped establish Aitken’s immersive installation practice.

short_bio: Doug Aitken is an American multidisciplinary artist whose work ranges from installations to large-scale projection on buildings and landscapes. Projects such as SONG 1 and electric earth immerse viewers in choreographed image and sound environments that often unfold across entire architectures.

references.title: Turning the Hirshhorn Into the Ultimate Movie Screen

name: Hannes Koch
focus_summary: Co-founder and co-director of Random International, creating immersive environments that respond to visitor behaviour.

key_works.title: Rain Room
key_works.venue_or_context: Barbican, London; MoMA, New York; Sharjah Art Foundation; and other venues
key_works.notes: Interactive installation where visitors walk through continuous rain that stops wherever their bodies are detected by tracking systems.

short_bio: Hannes Koch is a German-born artist and co-founder of the London-based studio Random International. Working with co-founder Florian Ortkrass, he directs large-scale experiential pieces such as Rain Room that merge technology, weather, and human behaviour into responsive immersive environments.
notes: Listed here as an individual creative lead behind Random International’s immersive works.

name: Florian Ortkrass
focus_summary: Co-founder and co-director of Random International, developing technologically driven immersive installations.

key_works.title: Rain Room
key_works.venue_or_context: Barbican, London; MoMA, New York; Sharjah Art Foundation; and other venues
key_works.notes: Co-created experiential installation in which visitors can walk through rainfall without getting wet, thanks to motion tracking and responsive water systems.

short_bio: Florian Ortkrass is a German artist and co-founder of Random International. Alongside Hannes Koch, he leads the studio’s exploration of human behaviour in technologically mediated environments, most famously in the interactive installation Rain Room.

name: Lonneke Gordijn
focus_summary: Co-founder of Studio Drift, choreographing kinetic light works and drone performances inspired by natural systems.

key_works.title: Franchise Freedom
key_works.venue_or_context: Art Basel Miami Beach; later performances in global cities
key_works.notes: Outdoor drone performance simulating a flock of starlings, using algorithms and light to create an immersive aerial choreography.

short_bio: Lonneke Gordijn is a Dutch artist and co-founder of Studio Drift, an Amsterdam-based duo that creates experiential sculptures and performances inspired by nature. With Ralph Nauta she co-choreographs works such as Franchise Freedom, in which swarms of drones form a living light sculpture in the sky.
notes: Ralph Nauta could be added as a separate but related profile in later dataset expansion.

name: Felix Barrett
focus_summary: Founder and artistic director of Punchdrunk, pioneering large-scale immersive theatre where audiences roam freely through cinematic sets.

key_works.title: Sleep No More
key_works.venue_or_context: Punchdrunk productions in London, Boston, Shanghai, and ongoing New York run
key_works.notes: Immersive reimagining of Macbeth staged as a free-roaming experience across dozens of detailed rooms, widely cited as a landmark of immersive theatre.

key_works.title: Viola’s Room
key_works.notes: Recent intimate immersive experience guided by narration and light, extending the company’s experimentation with game-like structures and audience participation.

short_bio: Felix Barrett is the founder and artistic director of Punchdrunk, the British company credited with defining contemporary immersive theatre. Productions such as Sleep No More place masked spectators inside expansive, filmic environments, foregrounding spatial narrative and audience agency.

name: Laurie Anderson
focus_summary: Avant-garde artist who extends her long-standing multimedia performance practice into VR worlds of text, drawing, and sound.

key_works.title: Chalkroom
key_works.venue_or_context: Presented at festivals and museums in the US, Europe, and Asia
key_works.notes: Virtual reality work created with Hsin-Chien Huang, allowing visitors to fly through a vast structure of words and stories.

key_works.title: La Camera Insabbiata
key_works.notes: Expanded VR project with Hsin-Chien Huang that received the Best VR Experience award at Venice, combining Chalkroom with additional narrative rooms.

short_bio: Laurie Anderson is an American artist, composer, and performer whose multimedia work has incorporated electronics, projections, and storytelling since the 1970s. In collaboration with Hsin-Chien Huang she brought her narrative and visual language into VR with projects such as Chalkroom and La Camera Insabbiata.

name: Hsin-Chien Huang
focus_summary: Taiwanese VR artist creating richly constructed virtual worlds, often in collaboration with Laurie Anderson.

key_works.title: La Camera Insabbiata
key_works.notes: Interactive VR installation co-created with Laurie Anderson, awarded Best VR Experience at Venice for its labyrinth of chalk-drawn rooms and narratives.

key_works.title: Ekholux
key_works.notes: Immersive VR puzzle and extreme sports adventure game blending sound-reactive puzzles and spatial art.

short_bio: Hsin-Chien Huang is a Taiwanese new media and VR artist whose work spans installation, performance, and interactive virtual worlds. He is co-creator of La Camera Insabbiata with Laurie Anderson and continues to develop VR experiences such as Ekholux that combine experimental storytelling with game mechanics.

name: Adrien Mondot
focus_summary: Co-artistic director of Adrien M & Claire B, creating digital-physical performances and installations where projected graphics respond in real time to bodies and movement.

key_works.title: En amour
key_works.venue_or_context: Touring immersive installation and performance, including BIAC and other venues
key_works.notes: Immersive and interactive piece at the intersection of live performance and visual art, where visitors move through a projection-filled space reacting to their presence.

key_works.title: Dernière minute / Last Minute
key_works.venue_or_context: CHRONIQUES Biennale des Imaginaires Numériques; PHI Centre Montreal
key_works.notes: Large-scale installation in which visitors walk through a universe of falling signs and graphical particles, blending data, time, and the body.

short_bio: Adrien Mondot is a French artist, juggler, and computer scientist who co-directs the company Adrien M & Claire B. His work focuses on the dialogue between physical gesture and generative graphics, designing bespoke interactive systems that turn stages and exhibition spaces into responsive immersive environments.

references.title: Adrien M & Claire B – Company presentation
“Last Minute”, immersive installation by Adrien M. & Claire B.
En amour – Adrien M & Claire B

notes: Listed individually as one of the two co-artistic directors behind Adrien M & Claire B.

name: Claire Bardainne
focus_summary: Co-artistic director of Adrien M & Claire B, bringing drawing, scenography, and graphic design into dialogue with real-time digital environments.

key_works.title: En amour
key_works.venue_or_context: Immersive installation and performance, international tour
key_works.notes: Interactive installation that merges Bardainne’s visual language with Mondot’s real-time systems, surrounding visitors with projected particles, typography, and light.

key_works.title: Dernière minute / Last Minute
key_works.venue_or_context: CHRONIQUES, Centre PHI and other venues
key_works.notes: Immersive environment where visitors walk through a storm of signs and trajectories, designed as a large-format visual poem on time and presence.

short_bio: Claire Bardainne is a French visual artist with a background in graphic design and scenography. As co-artistic director of Adrien M & Claire B she develops installations and performances in which drawing, engraving, and folded paper techniques extend into room-scale projected environments.

references.title: Artists biographies – Adrien M & Claire B
references.publisher: TEO Exhibitions / Adrien M & Claire B

references.title: “Last Minute”, Adrien M & Claire B – Realities in Transition

name: Leo Warner
focus_summary: Founder and creative director of 59 Productions, leading projection and media design for Olympic ceremonies, major exhibitions, and large-scale architectural light shows.

key_works.title: London 2012 Olympic Opening Ceremony (projections)
key_works.notes: Led the team at 59 Productions responsible for animation and projection design in Danny Boyle’s opening ceremony, watched by a global television audience.

key_works.title: Light the Sails
key_works.notes: Animated projection mapped film that transformed the Opera House’s sails into an immersive storytelling canvas.

key_works.title: David Bowie Is (exhibition design and media)
key_works.venue_or_context: Victoria and Albert Museum, London; international tour
key_works.notes: 59 Productions designed the projection and media elements that wrapped visitors in Bowie’s archive of performances and images.

short_bio: Leo Warner is a British director and projection designer, and the founding director of 59 Productions. He has overseen media design for landmark projects including the London 2012 Olympic Opening Ceremony, Sydney Opera House’s Light the Sails, and major exhibitions, blending storytelling with cutting-edge projection and LED technologies.

references.title: Leo Warner – interview on immersive AV and Olympics

name: Kate Dawkins
focus_summary: Designs and directs content for large-scale live events, ceremonies, and brand shows, specialising in projection and LED-based immersive environments.

key_works.title: London 2012 Olympic Opening and Closing Ceremonies – Audience Pixels
key_works.notes: Designed and directed animated content for the stadium-wide ‘audience pixels’, coordinating teams of animators and technologists to turn the crowd into a gigantic screen.

key_works.title: World War One Remembered: Passchendaele – A Nation’s Tribute
key_works.notes: Projection-led commemoration show using large-scale visuals to transform architecture into a memorial narrative space.

key_works.title: Brand and award show experiences (Earthshot Prize, Sibos, etc.)
key_works.venue_or_context: Global broadcast and live production venues
key_works.notes: Creative direction for visual storytelling across LED and projection for high-profile corporate and philanthropic events.

short_bio: Kate Dawkins is a London-based creative director and motion designer, founder of Kate Dawkins Studio. With decades of experience, she creates design-led content for spectacular live performances, ceremonies, and brand events, turning pixels and projection into large-scale immersive experiences.

references.title: London 2012 Olympic Opening and Closing Ceremonies – Audience Pixels

name: Michel Lemieux
focus_summary: Co-founder of Lemieux Pilon 4D Art, creating multimedia performances and urban projection experiences that blend theatre, film, dance, and immersive visuals.

key_works.title: Cité Mémoire
key_works.notes: Large-scale urban projection experience mapping moving images onto Old Montreal’s architecture, narrating the city’s history across multiple sites.

key_works.title: ICARE / Icarus
key_works.notes: Immersive piece where two participants become performers within a dreamlike visual and sonic environment based on the myth of Icarus.

short_bio: Michel Lemieux is a Canadian director and media artist, co-artistic director of Lemieux Pilon 4D Art. For decades he has created performances and installations that merge live actors, projections, and 3D imagery, including the urban projection epic Cité Mémoire and immersive works such as Icare.

references.title: About Michel Lemieux and Victor Pilon

name: Victor Pilon
focus_summary: Co-artistic director of Lemieux Pilon 4D Art, co-creating multimedia performances and large-scale urban projections.

key_works.title: Cité Mémoire
key_works.notes: Co-director of the evolving city-wide projection experience that turns building façades into immersive historical tableaux.

key_works.title: ICARE / Icarus
key_works.notes: Co-creator of the intimate yet technologically dense piece in which participants traverse a dreamlike environment informed by the Icarus myth.

short_bio: Victor Pilon is a Canadian director and visual artist working with Michel Lemieux as Lemieux Pilon 4D Art. Together they pioneer stage works and public installations that blend live performance with large-scale projections, placing audiences inside cinematic stage environments.

references.title: About Michel Lemieux and Victor Pilon

name: Jan Kounen
focus_summary: Feature film director who has become known in immersive media for Ayahuasca – Kosmik Journey, a VR piece simulating a shamanic ayahuasca experience.

key_works.title: Ayahuasca – Kosmik Journey
key_works.venue_or_context: Tribeca Film Festival; numerous XR festivals and exhibitions worldwide
key_works.notes: VR experience that translates Kounen’s personal ayahuasca journeys in the Amazon into a guided immersive trip, produced by Atlas V, a_BAHN, and Small Studio.

short_bio: Jan Kounen is a Dutch-born French director known for films such as Dobermann and 99 Francs and for his long-standing interest in shamanism. In VR he has directed Ayahuasca – Kosmik Journey, a widely exhibited immersive work that uses virtual reality to convey the visual and emotional intensity of ayahuasca rituals.

name: Ricardo Laganaro
focus_summary: Brazilian VR director and Chief StoryTelling Officer at ARVORE Immersive Experiences, best known for the award-winning interactive VR narrative The Line.

key_works.title: The Line
key_works.venue_or_context: 76th Venice International Film Festival; global festival circuit; commercial VR platforms
key_works.notes: Interactive VR story set in a miniature 1940s São Paulo, winner of Venice’s Best VR Experience award and a Primetime Emmy for Outstanding Innovation in Interactive Programming.

key_works.title: Fulldome experience for the Museum of Tomorrow
key_works.venue_or_context: Museum of Tomorrow, Rio de Janeiro
key_works.notes: Early immersive project using fulldome cinema to explore future-oriented science and sustainability themes.

short_bio: Ricardo Laganaro is an Emmy- and Venice Lion–winning Brazilian director working in VR and immersive media. As partner and Chief StoryTelling Officer at ARVORE Immersive Experiences he directed The Line, one of the most celebrated interactive VR narratives of the late 2010s, and has developed fulldome and 360° experiences for cultural institutions.

references.title: Ricardo Laganaro – MUTEK Montréal speaker bio

name: Mathias Chelebourg
focus_summary: French director creating VR works that sit between theatre, gaming, and animation, including Alice, The Virtual Reality Play.

key_works.title: Alice, The Virtual Reality Play
key_works.venue_or_context: Tribeca Film Festival; Cannes and Venice showcases; various XR festivals
key_works.notes: Immersive XR theatre adaptation of Lewis Carroll’s tale, co-created with Marie Jourdren, in which the audience becomes an active onstage participant.

key_works.title: Jack: Part 1
key_works.venue_or_context: Tribeca Film Festival; collaboration with Baobab Studios
key_works.notes: VR immersive theatre piece with Lupita Nyong’o, combining performance capture, animation, and interactive storytelling.

key_works.title: Doctor Who: The Runaway
key_works.notes: Interactive VR episode for the Doctor Who franchise, extending a major TV IP into room-scale VR with Jodie Whittaker.

short_bio: Mathias Chelebourg is a Paris-based VR director and experience designer whose work spans XR theatre, franchise storytelling, and documentary. Projects such as Alice, The Virtual Reality Play and Jack: Part 1 merge live performance, gaming, and animation, while The Runaway brought Doctor Who into interactive VR.

references.title: Alice, the Virtual Reality Play – Unifrance
Mathias Chelebourg – Cannes Immersive Jury bio

name: Lance Weiler
focus_summary: Director of Columbia University’s Digital Storytelling Lab and co-creator of immersive, multi-platform storytelling projects that mix film, games, and live participation.

key_works.title: Body/Mind/Change
key_works.venue_or_context: Canadian Film Centre; David Cronenberg: Evolution exhibition
key_works.notes: Immersive transmedia project combining web, data, and physical installation, recognised for its innovative use of story and code.

key_works.title: Project Immerse
key_works.venue_or_context: Columbia University School of the Arts’ Digital Storytelling Lab
key_works.notes: Ongoing project that uses immersive storytelling and a limited series format to explore digital literacy, deepfakes, and trust in media.

short_bio: Lance Weiler is an American storyteller, director, and educator recognised as a pioneer in mixing storytelling and technology. As founding director of Columbia University School of the Arts’ Digital Storytelling Lab he leads experimental projects like Body/Mind/Change and Project Immerse that prototype new forms of immersive and participatory narrative.

references.title: Lance Weiler – Digital Storytelling Lab profile
references.publisher: Columbia University School of the Arts

name: Michael Daut
focus_summary: Bridges digital fulldome, giant-screen cinema, 4D attractions, and corporate experiences, often acting as creative director for story-driven immersive science and brand projects.

key_works.title: Evans & Sutherland fulldome library (multiple shows)
key_works.venue_or_context: Evans & Sutherland / planetariums and digital dome theaters worldwide
key_works.notes: As writer/producer/director and later Director of Show Production/Marketing, Daut helped develop some of the first digital fulldome shows and a large library of immersive content.

key_works.title: Immersive media projects for Mousetrappe
key_works.venue_or_context: Mousetrappe / themed attractions and special venues
key_works.notes: Worked on media for themed attractions, 4D theaters, and special-venue shows as Director of New Business Development.

short_bio: Michael Daut is a Los Angeles–based immersive media writer, producer, and director with decades of experience in giant-screen cinema, digital fulldome, and 4D attractions. After more than 20 years at Evans & Sutherland he joined Mousetrappe, and he now runs his own company while serving on boards such as the Giant Screen Cinema Association and IMERSA.

references.title: Michael Daut – Giant Screen Cinema Association bio
Michael Daut – LA ACM SIGGRAPH presenter bio

name: Robin Sip
focus_summary: Leads story-driven fulldome and stereoscopic films that combine cinematic visuals with science narratives, often pushing technical boundaries in 3D dome production.

key_works.title: Dawn of the Space Age
key_works.venue_or_context: Mirage3D / planetariums and digital dome theaters worldwide
key_works.notes: One of the first 3D fulldome films, chronicling the history of human spaceflight.

key_works.title: Mars 1001
key_works.notes: Fictional yet realistic account of a future crewed Mars mission, widely screened in planetariums and dome theaters.

key_works.title: Dinosaurs at Dusk
key_works.notes: Family-focused time-travel adventure exploring paleontology and flight in a dome format.

short_bio: Robin Sip is a Dutch writer, producer, and director and the CEO of Mirage3D. He is regarded as a pioneer of fulldome and special-venue 3D cinema, known for productions such as Dawn of the Space Age, Natural Selection, Dinosaurs at Dusk, and Mars 1001, which are shown in planetariums and immersive theaters around the world.

name: Ryan Wyatt
focus_summary: Combines astrophysics, real-time visualization, and fulldome filmmaking to direct science documentaries for planetariums and immersive theaters.

key_works.title: Fragile Planet; Life: A Cosmic Story; Earthquake; Habitat Earth; Incoming!
key_works.venue_or_context: Morrison Planetarium, California Academy of Sciences
key_works.notes: Series of award-winning fulldome shows that visualise astronomy, Earth systems, and planetary impacts using real scientific data.

key_works.title: Science visualization at Hayden Planetarium
key_works.venue_or_context: American Museum of Natural History, New York
key_works.notes: Worked as science visualiser on data-driven planetarium shows and space visualisation projects.

short_bio: Ryan J. Wyatt is Senior Director of Morrison Planetarium and Science Visualization at the California Academy of Sciences. An astrophysicist by training, he has written and directed multiple fulldome programs, including Fragile Planet, Life: A Cosmic Story, Earthquake, Habitat Earth, and Incoming!, helping to establish data-driven science storytelling as a core use of digital domes.

references.title: Director, Morrison Planetarium and Science Visualization – Aspen Ideas bio

name: Donna J. Cox
focus_summary: Leads teams that transform complex numerical simulations into cinematic fulldome and large-format visualizations for planetariums and museums.

key_works.title: Advanced Visualization Lab dome and giant-screen sequences
key_works.venue_or_context: NCSA / numerous planetariums and giant-screen theaters
key_works.notes: Directed visualisation teams creating high-resolution data-driven scenes for fulldome and large-format shows such as Black Holes: The Other Side of Infinity and Dynamic Earth.

short_bio: Dr. Donna J. Cox is an artist and scientist recognised as a pioneer of cinematic scientific visualisation. As director of the Advanced Visualization Lab at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications, she has led interdisciplinary teams that convert large-scale simulations into immersive visuals for fulldome theaters, giant-screen cinemas, and broadcast documentaries.

references.title: Donna Cox – School of Art & Design, University of Illinois

name: Kenji Williams
focus_summary: Creates live and pre-rendered fulldome performances that pair NASA imagery and scientific data with original music to evoke the overview effect and environmental consciousness.

key_works.title: Bella Gaia (live show)
key_works.venue_or_context: Fulldome and performing arts venues worldwide
key_works.notes: Live performance combining NASA visualizations, time-lapse photography, and world music, presented in domes and theaters.

key_works.title: Bella Gaia – fulldome film adaptation
key_works.notes: Planetarium-focused version of Bella Gaia distributed through dome networks.

short_bio: Kenji Williams is an award-winning filmmaker, composer, and show director best known as the founder of Bella Gaia. His work blends NASA satellite imagery, data visualisations, and live performance into fulldome and stage experiences that explore the relationship between human culture and the Earth system.

name: Harald Singer
focus_summary: Uses fulldome docu-fiction to explore the intersection of quantum physics, cosmology, and spiritual traditions, often through character-driven journeys.

key_works.title: Cosmic Dance
key_works.notes: Immersive film about parallels between quantum physics and Indian Vedic wisdom, distributed as a fulldome feature.

short_bio: Harald Singer is a filmmaker and immersive director known for Cosmic Dance, one of the early artistic fulldome features that link contemporary physics with spiritual narratives. His work helped demonstrate that fulldome can carry philosophically oriented, story-based content beyond classic educational planetarium shows.

references.title: Cosmic Dance – Immersive Cinema Fulldome Movie

name: José Francisco Salgado
focus_summary: Directs high-definition science films synchronized with live orchestral performances, often presented in concert halls, domes, and large-format immersive environments.

key_works.title: Science & Symphony Films (series)
key_works.venue_or_context: KV 265 / symphony orchestras and science institutions worldwide
key_works.notes: Visual suites for works such as The Planets and Aurora Borealis, combining astronomy imagery and orchestral music.

short_bio: Dr. José Francisco Salgado is an astronomer, visual artist, and co-founder of the non-profit KV 265. He creates Science & Symphony films that pair classical music with high-definition imagery of Earth and the cosmos, shown in concert halls, planetariums, and large-format venues, using immersive visuals and music to deepen public engagement with science.

references.title: Science communication projects – José Francisco Salgado

name: Zee Dinally
focus_summary: Develops and curates a wide catalogue of fulldome shows for mobile and fixed planetariums, from astronomy education to dance and art-focused 360° films.

key_works.title: Immersive Experiences mobile planetarium catalogue
key_works.venue_or_context: Schools and venues across the UK and abroad
key_works.notes: Large library of curriculum-linked fulldome shows covering science, history, culture, and art under Dinally’s direction.

short_bio: Zee Dinally is a UK-based astronomer and entrepreneur who founded mobile dome companies Immersive Theatres and Immersive Experiences. As CEO and planetarium specialist, he has produced and curated a broad range of fulldome programs for schools and public venues, helping to expand access to immersive media beyond major fixed domes.

references.title: Mr Zee Dinally – Astro Speakers profile

name: Rocco Helmchen
focus_summary: Creates abstract yet emotionally driven fulldome shows and immersive installations that connect mathematics, music, and visual art.

key_works.title: Chaos and Order: A Mathematic Symphony
key_works.notes: Educational fulldome show visualising mathematical structures and algorithms to an original symphonic–electronic score.

key_works.title: Tempus.ruhr
key_works.notes: Immersive fulldome portrait of the Ruhr area, created for cultural events in the region.

short_bio: Rocco Helmchen is a German media artist specialising in fulldome, projection design, and immersive video. With works such as Chaos and Order: A Mathematic Symphony and Tempus.ruhr he has become a reference for mathematically inspired, music-driven fulldome experiences that often appear at international dome festivals.

references.title: Chaos & Order – A Mathematic Symphony – Fulldome Show

name: Ed Lantz
focus_summary: Pioneer of modern fulldome and immersive venue formats; co-founder of Vortex Immersion Media and long-time advocate for dome-based storytelling.

key_works.title: Vortex Immersion Dome Productions
key_works.notes: Creative and technical leadership for a range of dome concerts, immersive shows, and branded experiences.

short_bio: Ed Lantz is one of the most influential figures behind the contemporary fulldome and immersive venue movement. As co-founder of Vortex Immersion Media he helped bring dome-based concerts, live shows, and mixed-reality performances into mainstream entertainment.

name: Paul Bourke
focus_summary: Mathematician and visualization pioneer known for immersive dome research, fulldome rendering formats, and real-time scientific imaging.

key_works.title: Fulldome Projection Standards Contributions
key_works.notes: Introduced key techniques in image warping, real-time dome rendering, and spherical formats.

short_bio: Paul Bourke is a mathematician and visualization specialist whose work shaped the technical foundations of fulldome imaging. His research on spherical projection, dome warping, and immersive scientific visuals is used globally in planetariums and research domes.

name: Maura McDonnell
focus_summary: Works at the intersection of visual music, experimental animation, and fulldome immersive formats.

key_works.title: Nuit Blanche Fulldome Works
key_works.notes: Experimental dome compositions exploring rhythm, light, and motion.

short_bio: Maura McDonnell is an Irish media artist and researcher focusing on visual music and experimental fulldome compositing. Her dome works are exhibited in festivals across Europe and explore rhythm, form, and perception inside immersive spherical space.

name: Mark C. Petersen
focus_summary: Veteran dome producer and composer whose company Loch Ness Productions shaped multiple generations of fulldome content.

key_works.title: Loch Ness Productions Show Library
key_works.notes: A major catalogue of space-themed and educational fulldome shows distributed globally.

short_bio: Mark C. Petersen is founder of Loch Ness Productions and one of the longest-active composers and producers in fulldome. His shows and soundtracks have shaped the educational and atmospheric style of many classic planetarium programs.

name: Carolyn Collins Petersen
focus_summary: Writer and script developer behind numerous fulldome and planetarium shows with a focus on astronomy education.

key_works.title: Planetarium Show Scripts (Loch Ness Productions)
key_works.notes: Authored scripts for many classic space science dome shows.

short_bio: Carolyn Collins Petersen is a science writer and script developer for fulldome shows, known for her work with Loch Ness Productions and her astronomy communication across media formats.

name: Ethan Bach
focus_summary: Known for experimental fulldome and immersive media works distributed via Alt Ethos and the Fulldome Film Festival circuit.

key_works.title: Fulldome Art Series
key_works.notes: A series of experimental dome artworks blending audio-visual abstraction and interactive elements.

short_bio: Ethan Bach is an immersive media artist and creative director known for experimental fulldome works, VR projects, and installations. He founded Alt Ethos to expand immersive storytelling across domes and public spaces.

name: Dan Neafus
focus_summary: Longtime dome industry leader and former head of IMERSA, helping shape the standards and community of immersive dome media.

key_works.title: IMERSA Leadership
key_works.notes: Key organizer of fulldome conferences, standards, and industry initiatives.

short_bio: Dan Neafus is former President of IMERSA and a major organizer of the global fulldome community. He has directed planetarium programs and shaped industry-wide standards for immersive media.

name: Michael Shanahan
focus_summary: Directs immersive astronomy programs for the Saint Louis Science Center’s James S. McDonnell Planetarium.

key_works.title: Saint Louis Science Center Dome Programs
key_works.notes: Oversees immersive astronomy shows and public science experiences.

short_bio: Michael Shanahan directs planetarium programs at the Saint Louis Science Center and is active in fulldome education and professional development for immersive astronomy.

name: Kaoru Tanaka
focus_summary: Japanese generative and immersive artist creating real-time installations and 360° environments for venues such as TODA in Dubai, Art Basel Miami Beach and European museums.

key_works.venue_or_context: Theatre of Digital Art (TODA), Dubai and touring immersive venues

key_works.venue_or_context: Art Basel Miami Beach, Neues Museum Nürnberg and other international exhibitions
key_works.notes: Series of real-time rendered works shown in galleries and crypto-art contexts.

short_bio: Kaoru Tanaka is a Japan-based generative artist and creative technologist whose work spans immersive installations, 360° environments and real-time rendered wall pieces. Exhibited at venues such as TODA in Dubai, Art Basel Miami Beach and Neues Museum Nürnberg, Tanaka bridges new media technology with poetic, abstract imagery.

short_bio: Max Crow is a UK-based fulldome director and immersive designer best known for his work with NSC Creative. As creative director on shows like CAPCOM GO! The Apollo Story and We Are Stars, he has helped define cinematic, education-focused storytelling for digital domes and 360° venues.

short_bio: Daito Manabe is a Tokyo-based media artist, interaction designer and DJ who founded the studio Rhizomatiks in 2006. Working with advanced sensing, robotics, AR and real-time graphics, he creates immersive performances and installations for museums, public space and global music stages. His collaborations with artists such as Perfume, Ryuichi Sakamoto and Nosaj Thing, as well as large-scale commissions like the Rio 2016 Olympic Games AR segment, have made him a key figure in technologically driven immersive live experiences.

short_bio: Ralph Heinsohn is a German fulldome producer and artist based in Hamburg. Since the early 2000s he has created award-winning dome shows that treat the planetarium as a cinematic and artistic venue, pioneering entertainment-focused fulldome storytelling.

short_bio: Yves Pépin is a French producer, designer and creative director renowned for his pioneering multimedia shows and mega-events.
